title: 1.16+ Items
body:
Items have a totally new, and completely different format in `1.16.100` and higher. The largest difference between the two (outside of component differences) is that there is ***no longer any resourcepack item file***. 

Be sure to move *any and all components* from your resource file to your behaviour file. Do mind that certain ones are updated in their syntax, such as `render_offsets` (see `?render_offsets`) and `icon`, the latter seen in the following example:

```json
"minecraft:icon": {
    "texture": "jade_katana"
}```

Learn about new items here: https://wiki.bedrock.dev/items/items-16.html

title: 1.19.40 script fix
body:
**1. manifest.json**
get the latest manifest by ?script manifest in <#749802770957074502> 

**2. Imports**  *changed names of modules*
from
```js
import * as mc from "mojang-minecraft"
import * as ui from "mojang-minecraft-ui"
import * as ne from "mojang-net"
import * as sa from "mojang-server-admin"
import * as gt from "mojang-gametest" 
```
to
```js
import * as mc from "@minecraft/server"
import * as ui from "@minecraft/server-ui"
import * as ne from "@minecraft/server-net"
import * as sa from "@minecraft/server-admin"
import * as gt from "@minecraft/server-gametest" 
```

title: Block Geometry
body:
By default, 1.16.100 Blocks must have all pivot points set to `0`. 

This can be avoided by using Blockbench, and installing the plugin called `Bedrock Pivot Fix 2`. Simply go to `Filter > Fix Bedrock Pivots`.

Also ensure that the model is within an appropriate size.

title: Block Geometry Size Limitation
body:
Excerpt taken from the Custom Block Geometry release article:
<https://www.minecraft.net/en-us/creator/article/custom-block-geometry-release>
> 1. A custom block geometry’s size may not exceed 1.875x1.875x1.875, or 30x30x30 pixels.
> 2. The absolute bounds that a custom block geometry must remain within are 1.875 (or 30 pixels) from the origin, on each axis.
> 3. At least one pixel on each axis must be contained within the base 1x1x1 (or 16x16x16 pixel) block.

title: Block Light Emission in 1.16.100+
body:
Block light levels are decided based on a number between 1 and 15. However, the value can only be between 0 and one. The values are as follows:
```
1=0.07
2=0.14
3=0.2
4=0.27
5=0.34
6=0.4
7=0.47
8=0.54
9=0.6
10=0.67
11=0.74
12=0.8
13=0.87
14=0.94
15=1.0```

title: Block Model (pivot | geometry bounds)
body:
Block models default their pivots to `0, 0, 0`. If your block looks "fine in blockbench", but weird in game, then this is most likely the issue! 

To preview your model in Blockbench the same way you'd see it in-game, use the pivot tool and drag your pivots to `0, 0, 0`.
This issue usually only affects rotated parts, so non rotated parts should have no issues, even without setting pivots to `0, 0, 0`.

When working with blocks with large models, you might receive a warning like `[Blocks][warning]-geometry.<geo> contains [...] boxes outside the warning bounds of (-0.5, -0.5, -0.5) to (1.5, 1.5, 1.5)`. Do not panic! It is just warning you the model is unusually large, but everything will work fine anyways, so do not let this warning stop you.

title: Blockception does not Document Experimental
body:
The plugin is built around the idea of supporting marketplace-ready content. Therefore, it avoids experimental/beta/undocumented features unless vanilla files have been seen implementing it.

This thought should avoid situations where everyone starts using features. Minecraft either then fixes it or removes it, which causes developers longer developing times or discarding content.

It also goes that supporting experimental increases the workload of maintaining schemas by a lot.

title: Broken durability repairing
body:
You can use `"repair_amount": "context.other->query.remaining_durability + 0.05 * context.other->query.max_durability"`
to make your item repair correctly.

title: Can you detect chat?
body: From bedrock 1.17.30 stable and upper we are now able to read/modify/cancel the in-game chat with Gametest-API so custom commands are possible!

title: Can you edit Vanilla Items/Blocks?
body: Currently vanilla items and blocks are not data driven, so we cannot edit them yet. Some items may be able to be edited such as food items, but the vast majority aren't currently.

title: Can/Should we edit the player.json file?
body: Generally no, you shouldn't. That file could be changed by other addons, and could overwrite yours. If something you need is based on that file, your addon will most likely break if it's overwritten. Only edit the file if it's for aesthetics or is absolutely necessary.

title: Canceling Watchdog Termination
body:
**1. Required import**
```js
import {system} from "@minecraft/server";
```

**2. Cancellation of Watchdog Termination**
```js
system.events.beforeWatchdogTerminate.subscribe(eventData=>eventData.cancel = true);
```

> Available in @minecraft/server module via module version 1.0.0-beta and above.

title: Conditional Lists
body:
Conditional lists pick a single feature from a collection based on conditions; they are akin to “if-else if” blocks in programming languages. Once a condition has been evaluated as successful (as determined via success determination, the conditional list will select only that one feature for placement.

https://wiki.bedrock.dev/world-generation/feature-types.html#conditional-lists

title: DMs are not ideal
body:
When you ask a question via DM, you are restricting the total number of people who can help you from all potential server members to just *one*. Asking in the public channels is the best way to get a good, community-sourced answer to your question, allowing other observers to give their input.

While you are certainly welcome to DM with each other, please be aware it is against our rules to send unsolicited DMs requesting help.

title: Data driven
body:
Data Driven (at least in the realm of MC), means that something can be "controlled via the config files." The opposite of data driven is hardcoded

Essentially if something is Data Driven, it can be controlled with addons. If something is Hardcoded, it cannot be edited with addons as it is part of the core game. Something becoming data driven means something that was hardcoded is now editable by addons.

title: Detect Entity Hurt
Detecting Death with Commands
body: Example: <https://github.com/Hatchibombotar/graves-addon/blob/main/Graves_BP/functions/graves/death_detection.mcfunction>

title: Detecting Items in Inventory
body:
It is possible to test for items in the inventory, but not without using command blocks, or gametests or `hasitem` argument.

`query.get_equipped_item_name` is useful for testing for items in `main_hand`, `off_hand`, or `armor` slots, but it won't test the full inventory.

If you want to detect an item anywhere in the player inventory (for example if they pick up an item, or complete a trade), you will need to use command blocks. It is possible to `/clear` an item, to generate a redstone signal, without removing the item. To target a specific player, you will need some rotating scoreboard or tag to ensure a single player remains the target to run on.

You can check a page on wiki about `hasitem` argument here:
https://wiki.bedrock.dev/commands/selectors.html#has-item

title: Difference between VSCode and Visual Studio
body: VSCode (Visual Studio Code) is not the same as Visual Studio. VSCode is an editor that supports almost any file type and programming language. Visual Studio on the other hand is a heavy dedicated IDE not well suited to many tasks. Make sure you are using VSCode for Addon development and not Visual Studio.

title: Do not ping /DM random people
body:
**Do not ping or DM random people for help or otherwise. **
If you DM a person looking for help, you won't be able to get an answer from people who might know more about your question. 

Random pings are never good either <:dont_ping_lich:850305248622018570> ; 
no one is obligated to help you at random.

title: Does it work on Marketplace?
body:
Not allowed:
- Anything beta
- Anything experimental
- Gametest
- Shaders
- Guns, drugs, violence, religion etc.

Whats allowed?
Everything that isn't shown above. Custom items for example are allowed, as long as you don't use the new experimental components.

Pretty much, if it works in a non-beta, non-experimental world, and it isn't using scripts or shaders, its good.

Why did I see a map using Experimental?
Some maps get special permission from Microsoft to use Experimental. These are usually free, or intended specifically to show-off the new creator-features. You are unlikely to get the same permission.

title: Don't make addons based on the Vanilla Resource download!
body:
It appears that you downloaded the vanilla resource/behavior pack, and are building your pack inside of it. This is bad practice for multiple overlapping reasons:

1) It bloats pack size for anyone who downloads your addon.
2) It negatively impacts performance in game.
3) It makes it significantly more difficult to differentiate between what you added, and what is vanilla.

You should instead create a pack from scratch, by creating a blank folder, adding a `manifest.json`, and then slowly building up the required folders and files. If this is intimidating, you can reference the vanilla packs for folder structure and file-format inspiration.

title: Dummy Entities
body:
Dummy entities are invisible entities which are used behind the scenes for game-play purposes.
Dummy entities are a very useful tool, and the document (linked below) covers some of the ways they are utilized, as well as showing how to set up the resource side of things.
https://wiki.bedrock.dev/entities/dummy-entities.html

title: Dummy Queries / Dummy Components
body:
Dummy components are used to communicate between the entity file and animation. The dummy components themselves don't do anything, but once they are added they can be directly queried for. An example is adding the components minecraft:is_sheared and querying if the entity has this component with query.is_sheared. 

Read more: https://wiki.bedrock.dev/entities/dummy-components.html

title: Entity Behavior Priority
body:
Behaviors are components that make the entity do something. They are always in the form: `minecraft:behavior.*`.

All behaviors contain a `"priority"` field. This field is used to decide when/how often the behavior will run.

⚠️ In general, the more important behaviors should be lower, like 0, or 1.

When the entity is picking something to do, it searches all its behaviors from lowest priority to highest priority, and picks the first one that it can do. For this reason, you need to make important behaviors like `minecraft:behavior.nearest_attackable_target` lower than behaviors like `minecraft:behavior.look_at_player`. If the `look_at_player` is lower, it will always run this first when the player is close, and therefor will never move.

title: Error Handling
Escaping Characters
body:
In json, a string is created: `"like this"`. As you can notice, the `"` character is used to show the beginning and the end of the string.

If you want to write a string that includes quotes, you need to "escape" it, by using backslashes: `"a json \"string\" with quotes"`. In Minecraft, the backslash character will disappear before being outputted.

Examples:
```"/execute @e[type=item,name=\"Rotten Flesh\"] ~~~ give @p stonebrick 1 0"
"/tellraw @a {\"rawtext\":[{\"text\":\"Hello World!\"}]}"```

title: Events.* execution order
body:
**Hitting an entity**
1 entityHit

**Breaking a block**
1 blockBreak
2 entityHit

**Placing / pushing a block**
1 itemStartUseOn
2 beforeItemUseOn
3 itemUseOn
4 blockPlace / buttonPush
5 itemStopUseOn

**Hitting a block**
1 beforeItemUseOn
2 itemUseOn

**Using an item**
1 beforeItemUse
2 itemUse

**Using an item projectile**
1 beforeItemUse
2 itemUse
3 entityCreate

**Using an item charge start**
1 beforeItemUse
2 itemUse
3 itemStartCharge

**Using an item charge release**
1 itemReleaseCharge
2 entityCreate
3 itemStopCharge

**Using an item charged**
1 itemCompleteCharge
2 itemStopCharge

title: Feature Chances
body:
Scatter chance: chance that any chunk will attempt to generate *all* of the iterations of a feature
Iterations: number of times the game will attempt to place an instance of a feature if the scatter chance for that chunk succeeds
Count (ore features only): number of a block attempted to be placed *per iteration (vein)*

title: Files that open Minecraft
body:
`.mcshortcut` Launch Minecraft and load world
`.mcpack` Launch Minecraft and import resource/behaviour pack
`.mcworld` Launch Minecraft and import world
`.mcaddon` Launch Minecraft and import addon
`.mctemplate` Launch Minecraft and import world template

You can find this list inside
`C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\Microsoft.MinecraftUWP_<>\AppxManifest.xml`

title: Finding a Team or Dev
body:
This discord isn't suited for finding or offering paid work. We can't moderate these transactions, so we ask that you move to a more suitable place.

For a casual discord community, consider joining Skill Share: https://discord.gg/sZ7fkcN. 

For more long-term contracts, consider visiting Bucket of Crabs: https://www.bucketofcrabs.net/

title: Formatting JSON, JS
body:
Please format your code as code-blocks! This makes the text monospaced, and has support for syntax highlighting.

The format looks like this:

**for JSON**
\`\`\`json
{
    "example": 123
}
\`\`\`

**for JavaScript**
\`\`\`js
console.log("hello world", 123) 
\`\`\`

The character used here is the **backtick** (U+0060 \` `GRAVE ACCENT`). This symbol is usually at the top left of your keyboard, occupying the tilde key (~). On mobile, it will be on the second or third page of symbols.

title: Free Template for Terms of Usage
body:
**__Usage Conditions__**

**You are permitted to:**

- Examine the code and works to learn more about the creation and development of add-ons.
- Change the code or works to suit your needs.
- Use the add-on packs as you see fit in-game.
- Re-distribute the add-on packs or works elsewhere, with approval of the author.

**You are NOT permitted to:**

- Negate the accreditation of the original author.
- Paste the direct download link, negating the MCPEDL page.
- Take the author's code, works, and textures just to republish them as your own.

[PROJECT NAME] is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License by [AUTHOR NAME].
Permissions that extend beyond the scope of this license may be obtained from [AUTHOR LINK/SOCIALS]. 

*Note - You can modify this however you want to fit your needs. Good luck on publishing your add-on!*

title: Free Work
body:
If you want an addon made for you for free, you're most likely out of luck. The best thing you can do is watch tutorials and read guides so you can learn how to develop it yourself.

People won't work for free, but you can always offer to pay them to make something for you.

title: Getting Partnered!
body:
Getting partnered with marketplace is a _privilege_ not a _right_. There is no guarantee that your application will be accepted, especially if you don't have a strong portfolio. Even if you _are_ accepted, you should be prepared to wait for at _least_ a few months, and realistically you may never be accepted.

**How to build a portfolio:**
 - Release maps on MCPEDL
 - Release maps through a publisher
 - Have a meaningful, well organized, public image
 - Register as an actual company

title: How to ask a good question!
body:
Be specific and include relevant details about the question upfront.
• What are you trying to accomplish?
• If you have code, which part is not working?
• What have you already tried?
• Have you searched the Bedrock Wiki?

title: How to clear only one effect
body:
If you want to remove only one effect from player, give him this effect for `0` seconds.
Example:
`/effect @p night_vision 0` will clear night vision effect.

title: How to get more vanilla files?
body: Download minecraft.apk version that you need, rename it to .zip and extract. Then go to `assets` folder. Here you will find vanilla resource, behaviour packs and more.

title: How to remove block shadow
body:
There are three main reasons a block may have a shadow.

The first thing to add to prevent a shadow is the `minecraft:material_instances` component with face dimming and ambient occlusion turned off:
```json
"material_instances": {
    "*": {
        ...,
        "face_dimming": false,
        "ambient_occlusion": false
    }
}
```
The second is to set the `minecraft:light_dampening` component to allow all light to pass through:

```json
"minecraft:light_dampening": 0
```
The last thing to do—if at this point there is still somehow a shadow—is to ensure your block geometry does not clip into the ground, if you are using one. No element should go below y=0.

title: How to remove hordes of hearts from hud
body: https://youtu.be/Zwz9NJaPNQQ

title: How to teleport into another dimensions?
body:
If you have a loaded entity in the nether  (or another dimension) you can teleport to it, by using the entity selector as a coordinate. Example: `teleport @s @e[family=nether_waypoint]`

This is the only way to move from one dimension to another, other than using portals.

title: Incompatible Multiplayer Queries
body:
Some of the queries are incompatible in multiplayer. Known ones:
1. `query.is_item_name_any`  Use `query.get_equipped_item_name` instead.

If you found any others, ping a person with faq-management role.

title: Incompatible Popup
body: This popup is caused by the `dependencies` key within your pack's manifest. To solve the problem, either remove it entirely, or set your pack's `min_engine_version` to `1, 17, 0` and the `format_version` to `2`.

title: Installing bridge. v2
body:
bridge. v2 is a PWA, which is a new and emerging type of application. 

**To install:**
- Visit the editor at https://editor.bridge-core.app on a supported browser (Chrome or Chromium based Edge).
- Click the "Install as Application" button in the URL bar. You can also proceed through setup and create your first project and then click the "Install App" button in the sidebar.
- As of bridge. v2.0.1, you will now see an option to install the app as the first step of the setup process, to install from this, simply click "Install App".

**To convert your bridge. v1 projects to bridge. v2:**
- Update to bridge. 1.8 (bottom menu bar)
- Run the bridge 2.0 project-converter. 

**Is it really an application?**
Many apps these days are built using web technologies, including apps like Discord and VS Code, bridge. v2 is the same. 

**Once installed, you can:**
- Launch it without internet
- Launch it from the start menu
- Create a shortcut for it on your desktop 

**Getting started with bridge. v2:**
https://bridge-core.app/editor-docs/getting-started/

title: Is it possible to animate Blocks?
body:
You may not animate blocks in the same way as entities, with keyframes or math.
You *can*, however, animate the model or texture frame by frame; the model can be animated by sequentially hiding/showing new parts of the model.
Texture-wise, you may use block flipbook textures.

https://wiki.bedrock.dev/blocks/blocks-intro.html#block-flipbook-texture-definition

https://wiki.bedrock.dev/concepts/flipbook-textures.html

title: Item Creative Category Overflow
Item Translation Keys in 1.16.100+
body:
The translation key for all custom items is updated as of versions `1.16.100`+.

[ Old ]
`item.trhh:mysterious_sack.name=Mysterious Sack`

[ New ]
`item.trhh:mysterious_sack=Mysterious Sack`

Remove `.name` to update.

title: JSON Comments in VSCode
body:
If you don't want your comments be counted as errors, you can do the following trick:
1. Press `F1` then type: `Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)` and enter
2. Type:
```json
"files.associations": {
    "*.json": "jsonc"
}
```

This will automatically open json files as JSONC, so you no longer get error messages for comments.

title: JSON UI is tough!
body:
Welcome to JSON UI! 

If you are reading this, there is a good chance that you were inspired by The Hive, Galaxite, or some other addon or server. Welcome! This is the right place to learn about these topics. 

To get started in learning JSON UI, we recommend you check out the Wiki first: https://wiki.bedrock.dev/json-ui/json-ui-intro.html.

However, please be aware of these things:
 - JSON UI is much tougher than other addon topics.
 - JSON UI is 100% only documented from vanilla reference and reverse engineering. There are no documentation directly from Mojang. 
 - We will not give you step-by-step instructions on how to create UI from Hive/Galaxite. 

**JSON UI is one of the toughest addon topics, so please be patient. Try and attempt small tasks. Ask concrete, answerable questions. We won't spoon-feed you.**

title: JSON UI vs. HTML UI
body:
Json UI is created using json config files. It is used to edit *vanilla* UI. The current UI for the game is built using the json UI engine. 

Scripting UI, or html UI, is a new, experimental kind of UI that uses HTML and the js scripting engine. Its pretty much completely undocumented, and not considered particularly stable.

title: JSON is not a language... or is it?
body:
`json` is not a language, its a data exchange format, not unlike UFT8 or whatever. 

The behavior pack system in Minecraft, is, however, touring complete. Since the behavior pack system uses`json` as its syntax, `json` BECOMES a programming language in the context of Minecraft.

A language is just a fancy way of saying "A syntax, which either through interpretation or compilation results a valid program".

While it may be passively correct to claim that "json isn't a programming language", its pretty missleading when discussing Minecraft Bedrock content.

title: New `/execute` Pack Errors
No capital letters please!
body:
Do not use ANY capital letters in your addon. Capital letters are *not supported by the addon system*. Don't use capitals in your identifiers, animation controller states, folders, file names, functions, tags, events, component_groups, or anywhere else.

Yes, SOME places can support capitals, but that's not an excuse to use them. This makes a confusing mess of remembering where its allowed and where it isn't. 

No capitals 💢

title: Placement Passes
body:
Placement passes can just be thought of as a named ordering for when placement of a feature rule’s target feature should occur. *Nothing special occurs during a pass; it’s just a name.*

The available passes are:

- `pregeneration_pass`
- `first_pass`
- `before_underground_pass`
- `underground_pass`
- `after_underground_pass`
- `before_surface_pass`
- `surface_pass`
- `after_surface_pass`
- `before_sky_pass`
- `sky_pass`
- `after_sky_pass`
- `final_pass`

Note that the pregeneration pass is reserved for carver features.

title: Please don't use .rar!
body:
`.rar` is a proprietary format from the paid WinRar program. When you send a `.rar` file, you are requiring the other person to either pay for WinRar, or illegally use it. 

Please use the universal `.zip` format in the future. You can do so from WinRar, but I recommend windows default, or 7Zip.

title: Please, no screenshots or photos!
body:
Screenshots are hard to read, and photos even more so. This is especially true if you are using bridge or another tree editor, as this format obscures the JSON format.

We can help you best if you copy and paste your code here, or send it directly as a file.

title: Relative Coordinates
body:
You can use `~` or `^` in place of coordinates to specify the location the command was run from. Adding a number after the symbol changes the offset from the execution point.
The difference is `~` offsets are relative to the world axes, while `^` is relative to the direction an entity is facing, in blocks to the left, blocks up, and then blocks forward.

Examples:
`execute @a ~ ~ ~ setblock ~5 ~5 ~5 dirt` sets the block 5 blocks positive on the x axis, 5 blocks positive on the y axis, and 5 blocks positive on the z axis to a dirt block.
`execute @a ~ ~ ~ setblock ^5 ^5 ^5 dirt` sets the block 5 blocks to the left of the entity, 5 blocks above the entity, and 5 blocks in front of the entity to a dirt block.

You can also read about relative coordinates here:
https://wiki.bedrock.dev/commands/relative-coordinates.html#relative-coordinates

title: Runtime Identifiers break stuff!
body:
"I added a runtime identier to my entity, and now it has weird behavior".

Runtime Identifiers add hard coded behavior to entities. This hard coded information often includes things like entity name, health, or drop table. 

"Can I do anything about it?"

You can remove the runtime identifier. That's the only thing you can do. Don't expect to use runtime identifiers without consequences.

title: Scan Surface Features
body:
Every block across the surface of a chunk can be covered by a feature using scan surface features. For this reason, it is strongly recommended to choose a feature that only occupies a column’s space.

https://wiki.bedrock.dev/world-generation/feature-types.html#scan-surface-features

title: Scatter Features
body:
Scatter features are the most flexible and useful feature type available. Scatter features can:
- Distribute or reposition a feature any number of times within a chunk’s feature domain
- Act as a gate to conditionally enable a feature to be placed
- Execute MoLang within the current feature context

https://wiki.bedrock.dev/world-generation/feature-types.html#scatter-features

> uuid: `2bd50a27-ab5f-4f40-a596-3641627c635e`

***Bedrock Dedicated Server Only!***

> available versions: [`1.0.0-beta`]

> available versions: [`1.0.0-beta`]

**Default Module Dependencies Example**
```json
"dependencies": [
    {
        "description": "@minecraft/server",
        "uuid": "b26a4d4c-afdf-4690-88f8-931846312678",
        "version": "1.1.0-beta"
    },
    {
        "description": "@minecraft/server-ui",
        "uuid": "2bd50a27-ab5f-4f40-a596-3641627c635e",
        "version": "1.0.0-beta"
    }
]
```

title: Stable/Experimental/Beta
body:
**Stable**: This means the current, publicly supported version of Minecraft. Everyone plays Stable by default. 

**Experimental**: Experimental can be turned on per-world. If you want to use Experimental things in your addons you (and everyone who uses your addon) will need to turn on Experimental in their world. 

**Beta**: Beta is the most extreme "cutting edge" Minecraft. Beta is opt-in, meaning you need to install it separately. It will replace your stable Minecraft unless you use a version switcher. Beta players cannot play with stable players, and visa-versa.

**Marketplace:** Marketplace work cannot contain beta or experimental features.

*Sometimes we say exp instead of experimental*

title: The Beta breaks stuff!
body:
"Something is broken in the beta".

The beta is unstable, and buggy. This includes breaking old addons/formats, as well as inconsistently implementing new features.  

"Can I do anything about it?"

You leave the beta. That's the only thing you can do. Don't expect to use the beta without consequences.

title: The format for naming items in .lang changed
body:
**Old**: item.sirlich:hoe.name=Hoe
**New**: item.sirlich:hoe=Hoe

Essentially you just need to remove the .name

title: Tick Awaition
Trade Tables
body:
Trade tables represent the fundamental data behind trading item transactions for an entity. Trade tables are not standalone; they must be referenced from an entity component. Using the randomizing properties available to trade tables, trade offers, item counts, and cost calculations may vary across entity instances, even if all would point to the same trade table.

Explanation: https://wiki.bedrock.dev/loot/trade-tables.html

title: Tree Features
body:
Tree features generate tree-like shapes. Tree features allow for more customization than any other feature type, including:
- Setting wood and leaf blocks
- Adding tree face decorations
- Restricting foundation and intersection blocks
- Customizing branch frequency and angle

https://wiki.bedrock.dev/world-generation/feature-types.html#tree-features

title: Using relative JSON UI properties
body:
The following can be used as valid values on JSON UI properties such as `size`, `offset`, and `anim` type elements:

• `%` the percent relative to the parent element
• `%c` the percent relative to the total width/height of the child element
• `%cm` the the percent relative to the width/height of the minimum size of all the child elements combined
• `%sm` the percent relative to the total width/height of the sibling element
• `%x` the percent relative to the total width; and `%y` for the height
• `px` can be used to refer the number of pixels inside strings
• `+` / `-` can also be used to add or reduce the size accordingly as you want

Example usage:
```json
"size": [ "100%", "100%" ],
"offset": [ "16% + 4px", "100%" ]
```
Can also be used in `anim` type elements and animate relative to the position using `%`.
```json
"to": [ 0, "100%" ],
"from": [ 0, 0 ]
```

title: Using the `development_*_packs` folders
body:
The correct way to create addons is by using the `development_behavior_packs` and `development_resource_packs` folders. Storing your addons here will allow you to reload the world to see addon changes, and will prevent pack caching issues.

You can work directly in the world, or in `behavior_packs`/`resource_packs`, but you need an understanding of manifest-versions and caching to avoid issues.

We highly recommend using the `development_*_packs` folders.

title: We don't support cheating, griefing, hacking, leaking or trolling
body:
We do not tolerate cheating, griefing, hacking, leaking or trolling.

If you are reading this note, you have most likely asked or posted something that falls into one of these categories. Examples can range from creating hacks for Bedrock edition and breaking marketplace DRM, to crashing servers or posting leaked content.

Please bring these topics elsewhere, or better yet, don't engage with them at all.

title: Weighted Random Features
body:
Weighted random features randomly select a feature from a list. They are typically used to provide variation across a set of related features.

https://wiki.bedrock.dev/world-generation/feature-types.html#weighted-random-features

title: What Is MoLang?
body:
MoLang is a simple expression-based language designed for fast, data-driven calculation of values at run-time. Molangs structure is largely based on simple 'C' language-family style syntax.

Documentation: https://bedrock.dev/docs/stable/Molang

**Where is MoLang Used?**

MoLang is used in various subsystems within Minecraft Addons. For example: `Client Entities, Animations, Animation Controllers`, and more.

title: What are functions?
body: https://wiki.bedrock.dev/commands/mcfunction.html

title: What are scripts?
body:
"Scripts" are written in **JavaScript**, and talk directly to the **Minecraft API**.
There are two kinds, **Script API** and the older, deprecated **Scripting API**.

**Script API**
is a new JavaScript framework, which is frequently updated, and has active community outreach.

There is considerable investment in documenting the system and several developers working on it, it's likely to stay and likely to get developed further.

- This API requires the feature switch to be enabled on the world settings
- see `?script api` for the documention.

**Scripting API**

Scripting API is the original JavaScript API from Microsoft. Note that is is no longer supported and is fully removed from the game.

title: What format version should I use?
body:
"format_version" tells the Minecraft API which version of the add-on system to use for a specific file. Its sadly not as simple as matching the game version however, since some systems are not updated very frequently, so you may have to use an old format version with them!

You can read more about Format Versions here:
https://wiki.bedrock.dev/guide/format-version.html

title: What is Regolith?
body:
Regolith is a program that you can use to run various tools called `"filters"` to modify resource packs and behavior packs. The filters can be written in different languages and can have their own configuration. Regolith runs the filters in an order defined in regolith configuration file. The RP and BP that are passed to regolith as an input are copied to different location and than modified. The filter is basically any program/script which does something with resource pack or behavior pack.

Regolith is a tool which hopefully will help people standarize the scripts that they use to speed up their workflows. Minecraft addon system is far from perfect and its often necessery to generate a lot of code. Regolith may help with making these code generators easier to reuse. Use of regolith isn't limited only to generating code. Some of the filters could be used for different task like printing some stats of the project, uploading some files to the internet or looking for errors.

GitHub:
https://github.com/Bedrock-OSS/regolith
Website:
https://bedrock-oss.github.io/regolith/

title: What is contents.json?
body:
The `contents.json` file is meant to list everything in your addon for better performance. Here's a link to a more in-depth description:
https://wiki.bedrock.dev/concepts/contents.html

title: What is texture_list.json?
body:
The `textures_list.json` file is meant to list every texture in your addon for better performance. Here's a link to a more in-depth description:
https://wiki.bedrock.dev/concepts/texture-list.html

title: Why is look_at_player so slow/glitchy?
body:
`look_at_player` is a *behavior*. The first thing you should adjust is the, priority and the probability. 

The next thing to realize is that Minecraft has hard-coded concept of `body` and `head` bones (groups). The `head` bone is hard-coded to react FIRST, then the rest of the bones follow. 

If your entity has a head (like a dog), make sure to name the geometry correctly so that Minecraft can use this information. If your entity does NOT have a head (like a signboard, or a hologram), you should decide whether you want the entity to react FAST (name the top-bone `head`), or slow (name it `body`, or anything else).

Being aware of the bone names of `body` and `head` is one way you can make `look_at_player` react better.

Still not happy? Get over it. Its just sometimes glitchy or slow. The component is designed to naturally make entities look at the player. Its not designed to instantly snap to their location. Even in a best-case scenario  you will need to deal with the hard-coded interpolation.

title: bedrock.dev issues
body:
Bedrock.dev is built upon existing documentation provided by Minecraft. It is pretty much impossible to maintain this documentation, since whenever a new version releases, mojang deletes all the old documentation and replaces it with the new version. Any edits we make are erased.

Things like missing components, mislabeled queries or even outdated information is not the fault of destruction, and is rather the fault of Mojang. 

We are looking into making documentation fixes persistent, but until that happens there is nothing we can do.

title: bridge. Addon Editor
body:
bridge. <:bridge:892791393007861821>  is a powerful add-on editor designed to speed up your development process. It provides a rich editing experience for all files inside behavior and resource packs (JavaScript, JSON and functions) and provides a powerful work environment. Unleash the full power of add-ons with bridge. plugins and make use of rich auto-completions provided as you navigate through a file.

Link: https://bridge-core.github.io/
Getting Started: https://bridge-core.app/editor-docs/getting-started/
Discord invite: https://discord.gg/swYxDwf

title: query.scoreboard
body:
`query.scoreboard` is a special query, which functions different on the server/client side. 

**BP**, such as BP animation controllers: This query always works here!
**RP**, such as render controllers or animations: **Only works If the scoreboard is set to display.**

While this may feel like a bug, it is actually intended behavior. Microsoft confirmed that this is correct, and how the feature was written.
